State and local governments need much more support, not less. Senator McConnell‚Äôs threat to starve them of essential help and let them go bankrupt would only make this public health and economic crisis drastically worse. 

Read the full brief here: https://www.jec.senate.gov/public/_cache/files/a4b9d6c8-b521-4901-a6c5-c30d7adf3a82/mcconnell-is-wrong---forcing-states-into-bankruptcy-defies-logic.pdf

If Senator McConnell needed further confirmation that this is a bad idea, letting states go bankrupt was floated during the Great Recession & was widely panned. It has been condemned by economists, investors, public employee unions & Democratic & Republican governors then & now.

KEY POINT: Forcing states to declare bankruptcy would hurt states & deepen the current fiscal crisis. 

It is a tool used to restructure debt, and state debt isn‚Äôt even high by historical standards. 

More from @CenterOnBudget: https://www.cbpp.org/blog/mcconnell-argument-against-state-fiscal-relief-doesnt-stand-up

Several red states don't have state income taxes and many that do are often still heavily reliant on sales taxes. 

In a few months, the likely hit to red states will become more evident and they may face an even worse fiscal crisis than their blue counterparts.

Senator McConnell has also claimed that bailing out states would be a ‚Äúblue state bailout‚Äù. But that‚Äôs not true. 

This public health and economic crisis is affecting all states‚Äîcoastal and interior, red and blue. https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/map-reveals-hidden-u-s-hotspots-of-coronavirus-infection/

Senator McConnell claims the states didn‚Äôt plan for a crisis, but in fact Senator McConnell didn‚Äôt plan for a crisis when he helped passed almost $2 trillion in tax cuts in 2017. He should have been saving for a ‚Äúrainy day‚Äù or investing in infrastructure to increase productivity.

The states and the entire country would be under far less financial pressure if the President had taken minimal steps to fight the contagion in its early stages‚Äîbut he did nothing for weeks. The cause of the problem is at 1600 Pennsylvania Ave.

Senator McConnell claimed that states face a fiscal crisis because of poor budgeting‚Äîthis is false. Most states had strong ‚Äúrainy day‚Äù funds.

The real cause is obvious: an unprecedented public health and economic crisis. https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-04-22/mcconnell-says-he-favors-allowing-states-to-declare-bankruptcy

Making the position of BOP Director Senate confirmable will ensure that the American people have a say in this important role and that the BOP will remain responsive to their representatives in Congress.

After years of out of control spending and actions that run counter to institutional safety, especially during the COVID-19 pandemic, it is abundantly clear that increased oversight of the BOP is long overdue.

The federal Bureau of Prisons plays a critical public safety role in ensuring the very worst among us stay behind bars, but their utter lack of transparency and responsiveness to members of Congress and the public at large is appalling.

Despite the pandemic‚Äôs impact on the BOP system, the agency has continued to move inmates between facilities across the nation, often from hot spots to areas with few confirmed cases, leading to widespread concern among local communities, members of Congress, and doctors.
Thirty-three BOP inmates have died of COVID-19 while 1,692 inmates and 349 BOP staff have confirmed positive test results for the virus.

There are currently more COVID-19 cases in the BOP system than in Alaska, Montana, Wyoming, Hawaii, Vermont, North Dakota, Maine, West Virginia, the Northern Marianas Islands, the Virgin Islands, Guam, and Puerto Rico.

The introduction of this bill comes after several failures by the BOP leadership to take proactive measures to handle COVID-19 in the federal prisons system and ensure the health and safety of federal prisons inmates and staff.
Yet, unlike most DOJ administrators and directors, the BOP Director is appointed by the U.S. Attorney General‚Äînot the President‚Äîwithout Senate confirmation.
The DOJ Inspector General‚Äôs annual report called the BOP‚Äôs increasing costs a ‚Äúpersisting crisis‚Äù despite a ‚Äúdownward trend‚Äù in the federal prison population.
With a $7 billion budget, more than 36,000 employees and 172,000 inmates, the BOP Director oversees a massive government agency without sufficient congressional oversight.

The article quotes an analyst: ‚ÄúDid it come from a market? Did it come from a lab? We just don‚Äôt know.‚Äô 

I can only wonder how WaPo concluded from this that the lab-accident theory is ‚Äúdoubtful.‚Äù It‚Äôs not ‚Äúdoubtful‚Äù for WaPo. It‚Äôs politically inconvenient.

While I understand that scientists wish to defend their colleagues (and their funding), human error regularly causes lab accidents. For example:

https://www.the-scientist.com/news-analysis/sars-escaped-beijing-lab-twice-50137
The article also relies on praise from U.S. scientists who worked closely with researchers at the Wuhan Institute of Virology, as if this clears the lab of any suspicion.

The article tries to cast doubt on the lab theory, but there‚Äôs even less evidence for competing theories. 

We know the virus didn‚Äôt originate in that seafood market. As one expert said: ‚Äúthe virus came into the market before it came out of the market.‚Äù

https://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(20)30183-5/fulltext

The article downplays a growing body of circumstantial evidence pointing to the Wuhan labs. It even fails to mention some of the best reporting on this issue by none other than‚Ä¶ the Washington Post.

https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/2020/04/14/state-department-cables-warned-safety-issues-wuhan-lab-studying-bat-coronaviruses/

This May, join me in celebrating the unique history of #AANHPIs and the strength of our nation's diversity.

As a Representative in the most diverse Congress in history, and an Associate Member of the Congressional Asian Pacific American Caucus, I am dedicated to promoting, preserving, and protecting the culture and heritage of the AANHPI community.
I'm proud to represent a state with a flourishing Asian American community that has become our fastest growing population.

From Chinese workers helping to build the first Transcontinental Railroad in the 1860s to Filipino farm workers organizing and leading labor movements in the 1960s to being on the frontlines of our current COVID-19 pandemic, AANHPIs have shaped our country's story in so many ways

Today marks the first day of #APAHM. We cannot share the history of the United States without mentioning the great contributions of our Asian American, Native Hawaii, and Pacific Islander (AANHPI) community and we must take time to celebrate. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EW9VNnuUwAAlQ4F.jpg

The Smithsonian Learning Lab has created distances learning resources for educators, students, and parents as we navigate this time of uncertainty. https://learninglab.si.edu/#sll-discover

The National Gallery of Art has also recognized our responsibility to foster learning though our routines may be on pause. The gallery has children‚Äôs video tours, lesson plans, and other activities available to the public. https://www.nga.gov/education/digital-education-resources.html

With our normal routines on pause, it is critical that we maintain our focus on students and their education. Other institutions like the National Archives have stepped up and are providing online programs for students. https://education.blogs.archives.gov/2020/03/30/online-student-programs/

Additionally, with so many students facing difficulties navigating the new remote learning environment, the Library of Congress has also made available several educational resources for students. https://cha.house.gov/sites/democrats.cha.house.gov/files/LOC%20Digital%20Resources%2BR_0.pdf
